The freshers file

Freshers: Welcome to York

By James Bithell

Freshers' Week is upon us and for newcomers to York, there is so much to find out and so little time. Don't worry though: from making friends with your flatmates to swimming in the lake, second year Nicky Woolf has all the answers (or so he thinks).

Sam Noble and Sarah Foster discuss long-distance relationships and York's dating scene.

Are we all alone in the universe? Nick Pope, former head of the government's UFO investigations, isn't so sure. He talks to Raf Sanchez about the great 'unexplained'.

Go to a gig, attend lectures, have sex... Jenny O'Mahony explores a new virtual world.

Website downtime

Welcome back to nouse.co.uk. Unfortunately on Friday 13th July the website was hacked, causing the site to be down for over a week whilst we worked on a solution. Happily everything should now be up, running, and mostly back to the way it was. If, however, you find any problems please email tech(at)nouse.co.uk and let us know. <strong>Emma Gawen Nouse Web Editor.</strong>

Now's the time, guys: escape the rat race

By James Bithell

It's been over 30 years since Tony Wheeler, founder of the Lonely Planet enterprise, set off on his first trail-blazing trip.Venetia Rainey meets the man who has inspired generations of travellers to take up their backpacks and venture into the world of the unknown.

By James Bithell

For students with mobility issues, accessibility is central to their university experience, as Toby Green discovers

An orgasm of one's own: women who spank back

By James Bithell

For the generation of women reared on Carrie Bradshaw's writings, the concept of female empowerment now stretches from the boardroom into the bedroom. Sara Sayeed talks to three women who have chosen to pursue careers in alternative sex industries: those of lingerie, therapy and the aptly named 'cliterature'

'We're isolated. Our grief is killing us'

By James Bithell

Members of Britain's Iraqi community have seen their homeland destroyed by a dictator and now must watch it being torn apart by war. Raf Sanchez meets the people struggling to come to terms with the fate of the country to which they still long to return.

The real 'Ethical Man'

When I was preparing to meet John Cossham on a hot day in May, the last thing I would have expected to see on first entering his house would have been a blazing fire. Tales of composting toilets and appearances on Newsnight with the Ethical Man had led me to believe that this would be a man that would put any of my paltry efforts to live a green life firmly in the shade.

Tracing the Orient Express

Thirty years after the Orient Express made its final journey from London to Istanbul, Adam Sloan hits Paris, Vienna and Sofia to follows in its footsteps

Living green: on a mission to reduce my carbon footprint

Living a 'low-carbon' life is the green brigade's latest idea on how individuals can help halt climate change. <em>Toby Green</em> spends a week trying to limit his carbon emissions to see whether he can make a difference - without breaking the bank
